prefix: Approach the following question the way someone in high school would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone in high school would. If 52 cards are dealt to 8 people as evenly as possible, how many people will end up with fewer than 7 cards?
solution: When you divide 52 by 8, you get 6 with a remainder of 4.  Therefore, 4 of the people will get an extra card, bringing their total to 7, while the remaining $\boxed{4}$ people have only 6 cards.
gpt_response:
To figure out how many people will end up with fewer than 7 cards, we can first calculate how many cards each person would get if they were divided evenly. Since there are 52 cards and 8 people, each person would get 52 divided by 8, which is 6 cards.

This means that initially, each person would have 6 cards. However, since the number of cards cannot be divided evenly among the 8 people, there will be a remainder. To find out who will get the extra cards, we can subtract the 6 cards each person should have from the total number of cards available (52).

52 - (6 x 8) = 52 - 48 = 4

This means that there will be 4 remaining cards to distribute among the 8 people. The people who receive these extra cards will end up with fewer than 7 cards. So, there will be 4 people who will end up with fewer than 7 cards.
solution_prompt:

To find out who will get the extra cards, we can subtract the 6 cards each person should have from the total number of cards available (52).

52 - (6 x 8) = 52 - 48 = 4

This means that there will be 4 remaining cards to distribute among the 8 people. The people who receive these extra cards will end up with fewer than 7 cards. So, there will be 4 people who will end up with fewer than 7 cards.
